captions.text:
The moon is old - at least, it looks old,
since its entire surface is strewn with the

rubble of broken down rock and pockmarked
with scars from ancient asteroid impacts.

We know that rocks weather here on Earth too,
and that meteorites have made some considerable

dents over the years, but today Earth looks
reasonably fresh and new without widespread
craters.

Earth owes its youthful appearance to the
fact that its outermost layer is constantly

renewing itself - hiding its age. New rock
spills onto the planet's surface from the

mouths of volcanoes; magma is released at
the seams of ocean floors and cools to become

part of those floors; rocks metamorphose (and
mountains form) when continents collide; and

the sea floor is recycled as continents ride
over it.

The process of remaking rock doesn't just
make it look young, it makes it young - at

least, to us, because our best tool to date
rocks is to measure the amount of decay of

certain radioactive elements in the rocks.
And when rocks melt and reform anew, all evidence
of that decay is destroyed.

Normally this is great, because it means rocks
carry around a record of their age - the time

since they formed. For example, we can tell
that ocean floors are spreading because their

rocks are youngest near mid-ocean ridges and
get progressively older as you head towards

land, where they're often recycled by sinking
under continents.

However, because the earth remakes its rock
so much, and because remaking rocks resets

their built-in clocks, it's hard to look really
really far back into our planet's history

- most of the first solid rocks that formed
ages ago on Earth's fiery surface have probably
long since been remade.

That's where a resilient little mineral called
zircon comes in. Zircon is similar to quartz,

both in its chemical structure and in its
durability, so it sticks around a long time

after other minerals weather away. But zircon
also has two things quartz doesn't: zirconium,

which gives it its name, and small traces
of radioactive uranium. Uranium atoms are

similar enough to zirconium that they can
occasionally slip into the mineral's crystal

lattice in zirconium's place, but unlike zirconium,
the unstable uranium atoms eventually radioactively
decay into lead atoms.

Which is weird, because lead isn't similar
to zirconium, and so would never have ended

up in a zircon crystal on its own - so the
more lead you find in a zircon crystal, the
older it is.

And one of the oldest terrestrial minerals
ever found, quite possibly the oldest piece

of the earth we know of, happens to be a very
lead-filled grain of zircon found embedded

in sandstone in Western Australia. Somehow,
this crystal has managed to escape destruction

by erosion and volcanic eruptions and asteroid
impacts over the millennia, and while we don't

know whether it formed in the very first rock
on Earth, if it didn't then by definition
the first rock must be even older.

So despite earth's best efforts to hide its
age from us, uranium-lead dating of little

bits of zircon tells us our planet formed
at least 4.4 billion years ago. There's also

other evidence from meteorites that suggests
the earth is even older, but at bare minimum,

this zircon lets us say with confidence that
the earth is literally older than dirt.

comments.author: SuperGamer30

comments.text:
Good lord, so many evolution vs. YEC comments....

No, finding lead in a crystal is not 'proof religion is wrong.'   First 
off, all that can really be known is that "there is currently lead there." 
... variables happen.  Not everything forms the same and random events 
aren't always predictably random. 

But, assume that rock is 4.4 billion years old.  It, like much of our 
planet could have come from meteors without the earth being that old.  Or, 
it could have been on earth that long without going against anything 
biblical.    Yes, some fringe fundamentalists count back human history 
6,000 years and assume the universe is only 6,000 years old.   This is not 
a logical or biblical assumption. The biblical creation account could have 
happened over any length of time... perhaps instantly... or, based on what 
we can observe, perhaps it happened over billions of years. 

The idea that the speed of the earth's rotation should be used as a unit of 
measurement of time before the earth existed is a bit silly. 


Someone also mentioned the "can an omnipotent deity create a rock so big he 
can't lift" paradox.

... the answer is no.  If something has no limit, the impossibility of 
reaching a non-existent limit isn't, in itself, a limit.   It's not even a 
paradox.  Just a poorly worded question involving a very simple concept 
people overcomplicate.

It's like asking "if the universe is infinite, where's the edge?"  There 
isn't one.  Get over it. There is likely a finite area where matter exists, 
but just because matter isn't in an area doesn't mean there isn't space 
there for matter to eventually expand into. 

People need to stop being so afraid of the concept of infinite things.   
All the best stuff is infinite.﻿

comments.author: Dispel Illusions

comments.text:
The beauty of this dating method is that you don't require more than one 
sampling of the same rock. Since the halflife of uranium is very well 
known, you only need to know the ratio of the lead to uranium in the rock 
to know its age.

Also, a scientific theory has the weight of mountains of proof behind it. I 
suggest you familiarize yourself with the term scientific theory: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_theory

comments.author: Алексей Салихов

comments.text:
+Алексей Салихов Mainly what occurs is this. We measure the concentrations.

Newly formed rock normally would have 50% X and 50% Y. Over time it becomes 
45% X and 55%Y. Melt it, and it all mixes together and becomes 50/50 again.

Remember: We can only date things knowing what it started with, and things 
are recycled, and due to heavier elements sinking etc during melting 
convection will occur that causes it to mix about.

comments.text:
He is forgetting the problematic ASSUMPTIONS that go into any of the 
popular radioactive carbon dating measures.  He ASSUMES that the element 
decays at the same RATE over these so called billions of years, He assumes 
that the environment of the Earth has been the SAME for billions of years, 
and he simply does not know at what point in time did the decay start. 
 Hence WHY none of those types of dating measures when TESTED against 
materials of known age, are usually NEVER accurate!!!  The dating of the 
planet is IMPOSSIBLE for us to do as humans at this current time, and the 
AGE given in this video is obviously showing BIAS towards the Atheistic 
Evolutionist worldview (aka religion, but they will never admit that).  It 
takes GREAT FAITH to believe that the Earth is 4.4 Billion years old, when 
just 100 years ago the consensus among Atheists at that time proclaimed the 
Earth as being only between 100 Million and 1 Billion years old.  So the 
Earth is aging 3 Billion years, give or take an accuracy of .0000000000001, 
every 100 years the Earth ages.
https://answersingenesis.org/geology/carbon-14/doesnt-carbon-14-dating-disprove-the-bible/
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_the_Earth﻿
comments.author: Dana L

comments.text:
You clearly have no understanding of what carbon and zircon dating actually 
are.

Everything in your argument is based on the fact that carbon dating is 
inaccurate when measured against objects of known age, correct?
Well, the reason for that is that carbon dating does not work well on newer 
objects, AKA the ones we know the age of.  This is because half-lives are 
varied, but tend toward a central mean over time.  For example, imagine 
flipping a coin.  If you have three flips, you could get 0, 50, or 100 
percent chance of getting heads.  This has no central average.  However, if 
you flip hundreds of coins, or have hundreds of half-lives, it averages 
out.  Still not 100 percent accurate, but a darn good estimation.

Finally, I'm guessing you are a Christian.  I am also making the assumption 
that you think God created the earth 6000-10000 years ago.  To this I have 
one response: how do you know?  How do you know that God didn't spend a 
billion years creating the universe, as there was no definition of a day 
before day and night?  How do you know Adam and Eve didn't spend millions 
of years in the Garden of Eden, as it was an era before death?  Heck, how 
do you know God's not just trolling all of us by changing the proportions 
of radioactive isotopes, as he is omnipotent and mysterious?

I admire your logical deduction here, but everything you are saying comes 
from a very surface-level and narrow-minded knowledge of your sources. 
 Keep in mind that I am not contradicting your belief; I myself am after 
all a Christian.  I am just saying that you should look more into your own 
claims instead of blindly following what people wail on about.

Regardless of exact moment of origin, using an absolute timescale is not 
feasible. Say the Earth formed exactly 4,100,050,521bya. It's easier to say 
"It is the year twenty-fourteen" or "two thousands fourteen" rather than 
"four billion, one hundred million, fifty thousands and five-hundred and 
twenty-one."

To the subject at hand, it's 2014 depending on what calendar you use. 
According to the Hebrew calendar it's 5775. 1393 in the Persian calendar 
and 1436 in the Islamic calendar.
